comments: Largest number such that there is an n-coloring of the integers 1, ..., a(n) such that each color is sum-free, that is, no color contains a triple x + y = z. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jun 11 2013
references: Leonard D. Baumert and Solomon W. Golomb, "Backtrack Programming", Journal of the ACM 12:4 (1965), pp. 516-524.
R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, E11 and E12.
links: Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Schur Number.
example: Baumert & Golomb find a(4) = 44 and give this example:A = {1, 3, 5, 15, 17, 19, 26, 28, 40, 42, 44}B = {2, 7, 8, 18, 21, 24, 27, 37, 38, 43}C = {4, 6, 13, 20, 22, 23, 25, 30, 32, 39, 41}D = {9, 10, 11, 12, 14, 16, 29, 31, 33, 34, 35, 36}Note that the union of these sets is {1, ..., 44} and none of the sets contains three numbers (perhaps not all distinct) such that one is the sum of the other two. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jun 11 2013
